newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thailand, Philippines seek $2.4 bln trade by 2000.
newsitem.headline: Thailand, Philippines seek $2.4 bln trade by 2000.

text.p: Thailand and the Philippines said on Tuesday they had signed a bilateral trade agreement and set a goal of $2.4 billion in two-way trade by the year 2000.
Foreign ministers of the two countries made the statements at the end of a bilateral meeting on southern Phuket island.
"It behooves us to work together not only for bilateral interests but as our contribution towards regional peace and prosperity," Thai foreign minister Prachuab Chaiyasarn said after the meeting.

He said the governments aimed to have $2.4 billion in bilateral trade by 2000. In January leaders of the two countries said they wanted to expand trade, then about $1.2 billion a year, to more than $2.0 billion by the turn of the century.
Prachuab said the two countries were formulating a plan for joint investment promotion that should expand to encompass cooperation in third countries.
Thailand and the Philippines also agreed to further intensify existing technical cooperation programs in agricultural, scientific and technical fields.
Philippine foreign secretary Domingo Siazon said his country submitted a draft avoidance of double taxation agreement during the meeting.
"The early conclusion of the negotiations on this draft agreement will benefit our airline industries and will have enormous positive impact on our trade and tourism," he said.
